awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: Mathematical Modeling With Cultural and Community Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

A team of investigators from the University of Arizona will conduct research on the teaching and learning of mathematical modeling in diverse elementary classrooms in Arizona and Washington. Mathematical modeling skills are foundational as they connect core mathematical ideas to real world experiences through analysis, representation, interpretation, and revision. Mathematical modeling also supports enduring understandings and practices in mathematics, such as problem solving and generalization. While mathematical modeling has a strong tradition in secondary education, the increased content of college and career readiness standards requires an introduction to modeling in elementary school. To address this need, the researchers will: (a) advance foundational knowledge on teaching and learning mathematical modeling in grades 3 through 5; (b) refine innovative professional development programs to increase teacher understanding and practice of mathematical modeling that draws on student experiences and relevant cultural and community contexts; and (c) develop a set of valid and reliable measures to evaluate teacher and student learning outcomes related to mathematical modeling. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning, and has implications for education in both formal and informal settings. 

The project will be conducted as a mixed methods, multi-tiered design experiment. Across the three project years, researchers will iteratively develop and refine a professional development model with cohorts of teachers in Arizona and Washington who work in high poverty schools with culturally and linguistically diverse populations. The researchers will measure the potential for impact of the model on mathematics instruction and student learning. The proposed work to design mathematical modeling tasks is based on tenets of progressive formalization Realistic Mathematics Education (RME), which suggest that contexts matter for supporting student learning of mathematical modeling. The model integrates research on teaching and learning of mathematical modeling, and research on the role of culturally and community based funds of knowledge in teaching and learning mathematics. As students work on modeling tasks, they will produce artifacts that include evidence of reasoning and thinking. They will also be assessed by means of a Common Core aligned State-level Standardized Mathematics Assessment measure. Teachers will adapt mathematical modeling tasks, design lessons around those tasks, and iteratively refine a set of reusable tools for assessing students modeling activity. To measure impact on student learning, the researchers will use a two-group design to compare student learning in classrooms of training condition teachers with student learning in comparable, non-training condition classrooms. Since few teachers currently use mathematical modeling instruction in grades 3-5, a teacher comparison group to measure impact on teacher learning will not be employed. Rather, the researchers will use participating teachers as their own controls to examine changes over time in their understanding and practice.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematical Modeling with Cultural and Community Contexts (M2C3) focused on an essential high-leverage topic in STEM education research: teaching and learning mathematical modeling in diverse elementary classrooms. Mathematical modeling skills are foundational as they connect core mathematical ideas to real world experiences through analysis, representation, interpretation, and revision. Mathematical modeling also supports enduring understandings and practices in mathematics, such as problem solving and generalization. Furthermore, mathematical modeling draws upon a broad range of student abilities that can help enhance learning and engagement for historically underrepresented groups in STEM fields. While mathematical modeling has a strong tradition in secondary education, the increased content of college and career readiness standards requires an introduction to modeling in elementary grades. To address this unmet and urgent need, M2C3 focused on and met the following goals: (a) advancing foundational knowledge on teaching and learning mathematical modeling in grades 3–5; (b) researching and refining innovative professional development to increase teacher understanding and practice of mathematical modeling that draws on student experiences and relevant cultural/community contexts; (c) adapting and developing a set of valid and reliable measures to evaluate teacher and student learning outcomes related to mathematical modeling.

Across the four years of the project (including a no-cost extension), M2C3 researchers iteratively developed and refined a transformative professional development model with cohorts of teachers in Arizona and Washington who worked in high poverty schools with large populations of culturally/linguistically diverse students. M2C3’s model for professional development and associated resources have improved understandings about teaching and learning mathematical modeling in the elementary grades – especially for culturally/linguistically diverse students. M2C3 professional development resources and tools including modeling tasks are now publicly available to support educators across the country and the world (https://sites.google.com/qc.cuny.edu/m2c3/home). Additionally, the teacher participants (n=67) have become professional resources for their schools and districts, sharing their expertise about mathematical modeling tasks that connect to relevant cultural and community-based contexts. M2C3 also expanded opportunities for diverse elementary students (at least 2,100 students) to learn mathematical modeling, as they engaged in rich mathematical modeling tasks that were relevant and connected to their cultural and community contexts. These tasks promote student learning in ways that develop the conceptual foundation, quantitative reasoning skills, and productive dispositions necessary for future civic engagement, post-secondary education, and success in STEM fields. The valid and reliable measures resulting from this research have provided and will provide future researchers with methodological tools to systematically investigate teacher and student learning related to mathematical modeling.

We collected data throughout two summer institutes for participating teachers (in 2017 and 2018), and in monthly study groups during the   following two academic years. In addition, we interviewed and observed teachers in their classrooms as they implemented mathematical modeling tasks with their students. Using the M2C3-Scan as an observation tool, a tool we adapted from the MSCAN (Walkowiak et al., 2014), we conducted and analyzed over 90 classroom observations. To research the impact on student learning, we developed, tested, and validated a paper-and-pencil assessment, the M2C3 Mathematical Modeling Student Assessment (MMSA), to assess mathematical modeling competencies for students in grades 3 through 5. Our analyses demonstrated that the MMSA has a high reliability and low standard error for average modeling competency, which supports its use as a measure for grades 3 to 5. We analyzed the MMSA scores in comparison with state-level standardized assessment scores. Analyses of correlations between MMSA results and state-level standardized assessment results suggested some overlap. However and more notably, the MMSA uniquely measured student learning of mathematical modeling, which the standardized assessments did not measure well.  

Project findings and outcomes are represented in 7 journal articles and book chapters (published, accepted, or submitted), 5 conference proceedings, 24 conference presentations, and a book proposal (submitted). Published manuscripts include: “Engaging children’s mathematical knowledge bases with math modeling tasks in elementary classrooms” (Aguirre, Anhalt, Turner, Foote, & Roth McDuffie, 2020), “Engaging teachers in the powerful combination of mathematical modeling and social justice: The Flint water task” (Aguirre, Anhalt, Cortez, Turner, Simic-Muller, 2019), “Jumping into modeling: Elementary mathematical modeling with school and community contexts” (Turner, Aguirre, Roth McDuffie, & Foote, M, 2019), “Exploring the nature of mathematical modeling in the early grades” (Suh et al., 2019; Suh et al., 2018), and “A Didactic approach in mathematical modeling:  Raising critical consciousness within social and culturally relevant contexts (Anhalt & Turner, 2017). We also participated in an NSF Showcase in 2019 and produced a brief video describing the M2C3 project (https://stemforall2019.videohall.com/presentations/1603). In addition, in order to provide broad and accessible support for teachers, teacher educators, and teacher leaders for teaching and learning mathematical modeling, M2C3 resources and tools are publicly available through the website (https://sites.google.com/qc.cuny.edu/m2c3/home). This website includes culturally-relevant and community-based modeling tasks, lesson plans, and student work. Additional analysis and writing is in progress.
